text: We will hear argument next in 75-699 Mathews against Goldfarb.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
Mr. Jones, it is been a while that I have read these briefs in this case, they might write in understanding that the basic PIA test is applicable alike to males and females.
That is correct Mr. Justice Stewart.
That is only this additional test that differentiates...
That is correct, it is correct.
...between men and women.
The problem in this case is that the support test does not apply to women.
Mr. Jones I am also a little rusty on the case.
It is not in the record Mr. Justice Stevens.
Yeah, but if he were -- if the genders were reversed she would get this windfall, right?
That is correct Mr. Justice Stewart that is the loophole.
Well, anytime if somebody does not like a provision of the law he calls it a loophole, this is a provision of the law.
Sometimes they call it unconstitutional.
Well that is the question in this case, isn’t it?
That is correct Mr. Justice Stewart.
Would it not be correct that the decision not to require a support test in the converse situation is just justified by administrative convenience?
It is justified by several factors and administrative convenience is one of them.
What are the others?
It is not rooted in the administrative convenience.
Does not your argument suggest that there is not necessarily a correlation between the ability to pass the support test and probable need at the time of the applicant applies for benefits?
That is certainly true as to widows and it was truer perhaps, in 1939 than it is today.
Would have thought for support test.
Would have thought for support test, that is correct.
But I suppose there are some widowers who are needy, but who cannot pass the support test.
It depends upon what you mean by needy Mr. Justice White, it is conceivable that there may…
I mean what is considerable as a support test, what is the purpose of the support test in the first place?
To weed out the non needy basically.
Oh, yes to weed out the needy which implies that there are some that are not needy or you would not have to weed anybody out.
Well, I think as a practical matter -- well, it implies that some are not -- excuse me, I misunderstand you, implies that some widowers are not needy…
Well, my additional question was, aren't there some widowers who are needy even though they can not pass the support test?
Again, Mr. Justice White, I say that that may well depend upon the standard of neediness that you use in a welfare system.
Has the man involved in this case ever indicated that he was needy?
He has not, it was our understanding that…
Would the case here be any different if he had?
Well, it would certainly be more attractive on facts for the other side.
